thread.title: Dodgers and Mattingly part ways in mutual agreement
thread.title_full: Dodgers and Mattingly part ways in mutual agreement

author: BETH HARRIS, AP Sports Writer
title: Dodgers and Mattingly part ways in mutual agreement
text: Dodgers and Mattingly part ways in mutual agreement BETH HARRI , Associated Press By BETH HARRIS, AP Sports Writer Updated 6:19 pm, Thursday, October 22, 2015 Photo: Frank Franklin II, AP Image 1 of / 8 Close Image 1 of 8 In this Monday, Oct. 12, 2015, file photo, Los Angeles Dodgers manager Don Mattingly speaks during a news conference before Game 3 of baseball’s National League Division Series against the New York Mets in New York. A person familiar with the decision tells The Associated Press that Don Mattingly is out as manager of the Dodgers. The person spoke on the condition of anonymity Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015, because the team has not announced his departure. In this Monday, Oct. 12, 2015, file photo, Los Angeles Dodgers manager Don Mattingly speaks during a news conference before Game 3 of baseball’s National League Division Series against the New York Mets in ... more Image 2 of 8 FILE - In this Oct. 12, 2015, file photo, Los Angeles Dodgers manager Don Mattingly arrives for a news conference before Game 3 of baseball’s National League Division Series against the New York Mets at CitiField in New York. A person familiar with the decision tells The Associated Press that Don Mattingly is out as manager of the Dodgers. The person spoke on the condition of anonymity Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015, because the team has not announced his departure FILE - In this Oct. 12, 2015, file photo, Los Angeles Dodgers manager Don Mattingly arrives for a news conference before Game 3 of baseball’s National League Division Series against the New York Mets at ... more Image 3 of 8 Dodger President of Baseball Operations Andrew Friedman, right, joined by General Manager Farhan Zaidi, speaks during a news conference in Los Angeles on Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015. Don Mattingly won't return as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers next year after agreeing with his bosses that he and the team needed a fresh start. (AP Photo/Richard Vogel Dodger President of Baseball Operations Andrew Friedman, right, joined by General Manager Farhan Zaidi, speaks during a news conference in Los Angeles on Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015. Don Mattingly won't return as ... more Image 4 of 8 Dodger President of Baseball Operations Andrew Friedman, right, is joined by General Manager Farhan Zaidi, during a news conference in Los Angeles on Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015. Don Mattingly won't return as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers next year after agreeing with his bosses that he and the team needed a fresh start. Dodger President of Baseball Operations Andrew Friedman, right, is joined by General Manager Farhan Zaidi, during a news conference in Los Angeles on Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015. Dodger's General Manager Farhan Zaidi, listens during a news conference in Los Angeles on Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015. Dodger President of Baseball Operations Andrew Friedman, speaks during a news conference in Los Angeles on Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015. Don Mattingly won't return as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers next year ... more Image 7 of 8 Dodger President of Baseball Operations Andrew Friedman, speaks during a news conference in Los Angeles on Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015. Don Mattingly won't return as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers next year after agreeing with his bosses that he and the team needed a fresh start. Dodger President of Baseball Operations Andrew Friedman, speaks during a news conference in Los Angeles on Thursday, Oct. 22, 2015. Don Mattingly won't return as manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers next year ... more Image 8 of 8 Dodgers and Mattingly part ways in mutual agreement 1 / 8 Back to Gallery LOS ANGELES (AP) — Don Mattingly and the Los Angeles Dodgers stuck to their scripts Thursday, insisting they agreed to a mutual parting of the ways while never revealing the exact reason he won't return as manager. Like a publicist announcing the demise of a Hollywood marriage, the parties insisted the split was amicable. Mattingly even suggested he "will be friends like forever" with his former bosses. "I don't really want to get into details of our conversations. They were good conversations, they were open and they were honest," Mattingly said by phone from his offseason home in Evansville, Indiana. "It just became evident that this was the best thing for both parties." Related Stories
